chapter: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 1: What is the embryonic origin of the lens?
questions.explanation:
The lens of the eye originates embryonically from the surface ectoderm. Surface ectoderm gives rise to lens, conjunctival and corneal epithelium and epithelial lining of 
lacrimal glands and tarsal glands.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 2: Where are the youngest fibers of the lens present?
questions.explanation:
The youngest fibers of the lens are the peripheral part, the cortex. The nucleus of the lens is the central part containing the oldest fibers. The lens fibers are produced by mitosis of the epithelial cells in the pre-equatorial zone. As the 
lens fibers elongate and the new ones are formed, the older ones are pushed towards the depth of 
the lens so that the youngest fibers are the most superficially located. 268 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 3: At a routine ophthalmological check-up, a patient was found to have bilateral, Y-shaped lens 
opacities as shown below. He was diagnosed with suture cataracts. Which zone of the lens 
nucleus is not involved here? 258 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The primary fibers in the embryonic nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures. The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowly 
progressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention. Types of lens nucleus and their age of development: • Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation • Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth • Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty • Adult nucleus As lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibers 
meet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures. Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation. 269 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 4: What is the ligament of Weigert?

options.a: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens
options.d: Attachment of the lens to the ciliary muscles

questions.explanation:
The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior 
capsule of the lens. It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached 
to the posterior aspect of the lens. Erggelet’s or Berger’s space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential space 
between the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and courses 
posteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in the 
embryonic vitreous. Posteriorly, Cloquet’s canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch is 
known as the area of Martegiani. 270 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 5: Where does the crystalline lens derive its nutrition from?
questions.explanation:
The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor. The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, to 
some extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source. Major intrinsic 
protein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin 0 in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency by 
transporting water and glycerol across the lens. Anti-oxidant mechanisms in the lens: • Reduced glutathione (most important) • Glutathione peroxidase • Superoxide dismutase • Catalase • Vitamin C, Vitamin E, carotenoids.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 6: While studying the histological anatomy of the lens, you are measuring the thickness of the 
lens capsule in various areas. At which of the following zones would you get the lowest 
measurement?
questions.explanation:
The lens capsule is the thinnest at the posterior pole, measuring 4 µm. Other options: Option A: At the anterior pole, the thickness of lens capsule is 14 µm. Option C: In the pre-equator region, lens capsule is the thickest, measuring 23 µm. Option D: At the equator, as shown in the illustration below, the thickness is 17 µm. 271 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 7: You are observing the given slide in a histology examination. Where is the marked structure 
absent?
questions.explanation:
The slide shows the histology of the lens and the structure marked in the subcapsular 
epithelium. The epithelium of the lens is absent on its posterior surface. The lens epithelium is a single layer of cells on the anterior surface of the lens. There is no 
epithelium on the posterior surface, as these cells are used up in filling the central cavity of the 
lens vesicle during the development of the lens. The anterior epithelial lining creates new lens 
fibers throughout a person's life.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 8: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced state by  
. 260 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional state 
by glutathione. Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. One 
of its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lens 
transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates and 
protects the lens from oxidative stress. The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays 
(295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily on 
superoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase. With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantly 
decrease.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 9: As part of a public health initiative, screening for cataract is being carried out. What is the 
most common cause of this healthcare issue in the population?
questions.explanation:
272 
Sold by @itachibot The most common cause of cataracts is ageing, specifically senile (age-related) cataract. Important causes of cataract: • Aging (Most common) • Congenital cataract (crystallin gene - CRYAA, CRYAB, CRYGC, CRYGS) (Option A) • Diabetes mellitus (Option B) • Syndermatotic- atopic dermatitis is the most common skin condition associated with cataract • Galactosemia- reversible cataract • Radiation- UV rays, X-rays, gamma rays, infrared • Toxic agents- Corticosteroids, miotics (long-acting anticholinesterases, e.g., echothiophate) 
(Option C) • Obesity Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related 
cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard 
cataract)-25%. In cortical cataract, the cuneiform type (70%) is the most common, and the 
cupuliform type is the most visually handicapping.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 10: You are compiling a literature review on congenital cataracts diagnosed in the last few years. 
Which of the following is the most common type?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of congenital cataract is the blue-dot cataract. Cataracta-punctata-caerulea, commonly known as blue dot cataract, is a prevalent type of 
congenital cataract. It typically develops during the first two decades of life. This condition is 
characterized by distinctive rounded bluish opacities located in the peripheral region of the 
adolescent nucleus and the deeper cortical layers of the lens. While these opacities are generally 
stationary and do not impair vision, larger ones may cause slight visual disturbance.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 11: The parents of a child have been informed at a PTA meeting that he has a lot of incomplete 
classwork. On being questioned, the child complains that he is unable to see things clearly 
and is having difficulty in reading and writing. On ophthalmic examination, he is found to 
have a cataract. Which type of congenital cataract most commonly presents with these 
findings?
questions.explanation:
Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with 
visual impairment. The etiology may be either genetic or environmental in origin. • Genetic- familial autosomal-dominant • Environmental form is associated with: • Vitamin D deficiency • Hypocalcemia • Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation 
may also cause lamellar cataract. The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear. 273 
Sold by @itachibot Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 12: A 33-year-old woman delivers a baby girl with a congenital rash, as shown below, and patent 
ductus arteriosus. What type of cataract is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario showing blueberry muffin rash, combined with patent ductus arteriosus in a 
baby girl, suggests a diagnosis of congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with a 
progressive, pearly white nuclear cataract. Ocular effects of rubella: • Microphthalmia • Rubella keratitis • Angle-closure glaucoma • Nuclear pearly cataract • Salt and pepper fundus (a most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 13: The following finding is found on the ophthalmologic examination of an 18-year-old girl. 
What is the most likely diagnosis? 262 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image above characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract, featuring multiple refractile 
colors commonly observed in myotonic dystrophy. Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by difficulty relaxing 
skeletal muscles after contraction. The initial symptoms typically manifest during adolescence or 
early adulthood. Cataracts are an early and prominent feature in 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy. They 
typically present as fine, dust-like opacities interspersed with iridescent, polychromatic spots in 
the cortical layer beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule, resembling a Christmas tree. 
These cataracts may remain stable or progress. 274 
Sold by @itachibot Surgical outcomes are generally favourable.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 14: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the findings shown below. She 
has been diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage of the cataract.
questions.explanation:
The above image represents an advanced stage of cataract progression characteristic of a 
Morgagnian hyper-mature cataract. Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens 
is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its 
position altering with a change in the position of the head. Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related 
cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard 
cataract)-25%. Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types. Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments. These 
are cataracta brunescens (brown), cataracta nigra (black), cataracta rubra (red). Cuneiform(70%) 
Posterior subcapsular/Cupulif 
orm(5%) Central saucer-shaped opacit 
y in the posterior cortex just 
below the capsule Radial spoke-like opacity star 
ting in the periphery and ext 
ending centrally Late visual loss 
Early loss of visual acuity; m 
ost visually handicapping sen 
ile cataract
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 15: Where is polychromatic luster noted?
questions.explanation:
Polychromatic luster is seen in complicated cataracts. Due to disturbances in nutrition of the lens due to inflammatory/degenerative disease of other 
parts of the eye like iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors. In inflammations/degenerations 
affecting the posterior segment, a characteristic opacification is seen in the posterior part of the 
cortex in the axial region (posterior subcapsular cataract). These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster. Even in the 
early stages, vision is impaired.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 16: Who among the following patients can potentially develop drug-induced cataracts?
questions.explanation:
Patients taking dexamethasone (corticosteroid) are prone to drug-induced cataracts, 
predominantly presenting as discoid posterior subcapsular cataracts. 275 
Sold by @itachibot Drugs causing cataracts: Other options: Option A: Zoledronate, a bisphosphonate drug can cause orbital inflammation, uveitis, and 
scleritis. Option B: Hydroxychloroquine, a drug used in malaria and rheumatoid arthritis, does not cause 
cataracts, chloroquine does. It can rarely cause retinal toxicity. Option D: Ethambutol is used in anti-tubercular therapy and its use has been shown to cause optic 
neuritis. Drugs 
Type of cataract Corticosteroids 
Discoid, posterior subcapsula 
r Anterior subcapsular Anticholinesterase 
s Chlorpromazine 
Yellow-brown anterior capsul

Posterior subcapsular Chloroquine

psular Amiodarone 
Anterior subcapsular
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 17: The ophthalmologic examination on a 23-year-old college student revealed the following 
image. What disease is commonly associated with this ocular finding? 264 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given picture of a slit-lamp biomicroscope examination depicts the anterior lenticonus, which 
is associated with Alport syndrome. In Alport’s syndrome, both anterior and posterior lenticonus are seen, but anterior lenticonus is 
more common. The diagnosis of lenticonus is typically confirmed through slit-lamp examination. Note: Lowe’s syndrome is an oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome characterized by congenital cataract, 
glaucoma, and posterior lenticonus
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 18: A 60-year-old man, diagnosed with bilateral cataracts two months ago, reports being able to 
read better without prescription glasses. However, he complains that his distant vision has 
become blurrier. Which type of cataract typically causes this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
The phenomenon described is the second sight of old age, seen in nuclear cataracts. Due to nuclear sclerosis, there is an increase in the refractive index, causing progressive myopia. 
A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. This 
improvement in vision is termed second sight. 276 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 19: A 38-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8 years. Her 
sugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract will 
be characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.explanation:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract. Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the 
lens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in 
secondary osmotic overhydration.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 20: A 55-year-old woman presents with an inability to see objects in bright light. On examination, 
she is diagnosed with a cataract. In which of the following cataract is this characteristic 
finding not seen?
questions.explanation:
The inability to see objects in bright light is not a feature of cuneiform cataract, as the lens opacity 
is peripheral, allowing visibility in bright light during miosis. The loss of the ability to see objects in bright light is a feature of posterior subcapsular cataract 
(visually handicapping), cupuliform cataract and nuclear cataract as these present with central 
opacities. When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction). These central 
opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays. Therefore, 
there is an inability to see objects in bright light. However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis 
(dilatation of the pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in 
dim-light vision. Furthermore, the complicated cataract, steroid-induced cataract, radiation-induced mainly 
present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 21: You are counseling the parents of Nisha, a 1-month-old child diagnosed with a congenital 
lamellar cataract in both eyes. What is the course of treatment you would advise?

options.c: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
options.d: Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant

questions.explanation:
Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in 
congenital cataracts. 277 
Sold by @itachibot It involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and 
anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens 
(PCIOL) is implanted. The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual 
deprivation disorders is 2–4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision 
must be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred. • Bilateral dense cataract- early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age • Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis- urgent surgery within days Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is contraindicated in children.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question:
Question 22: A 28-year-old girl is being evaluated for an aortic root aneurysm. She says her mother died of 
an aortic dissection at the age of 43. She is tall and slim. A musculoskeletal system finding is 
shown below. What is the most common lens subluxation noted in the genetic disease she is 
suffering from? 266 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette of a girl with tall, slim stature, an aortic arch aneurysm, Steinberg sign 
(positive thumb sign), and similar family history suggest a diagnosis of Marfan’s syndrome. It is 
most commonly associated with a superotemporal subluxation of the lens. The image below shows a subluxated lens in a patient with Marfan's syndrome. Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis. Types of ectopia lentis are as follows: • Simple type • Ectopia lentis et pupillae (pupil also displaced in opposite direction) • Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes • Marfan’s syndrome- superotemporal subluxation of lens • Homocystinuria- inferonasal subluxation of the lens • Weill–Marchesani- downward, forward subluxation of the lens. 278 
Sold by @itachibot • Ehler–Danlos syndrome
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following diseases does not show a specific pattern of cataract?
questions.explanation:
A specific pattern of cataract is not seen in leprosy. A specific pattern of cararact is seen in the following: • Juvenile diabetes: Snowflake cataract • Myotonic dystrophy: Christmas tree cataract • Wilson's disease: Sunflower cataract 279 
Sold by @itachibot Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Introduction  Types of Cataract and Clin
